entry.content:
Dear team,

Can you guide how to create validation for Special price  

CNT1:=0;
IF :OBJECT_TYPE='7' AND (:TRANSACTION_TYPE='A' OR  :TRANSACTION_TYPE='U') THEN
 
 
 
select count("CardCode") INTO CNT1 from ospp ---TO_NVARCHAR(CURRENT_TIME, 'HH24:MI')
where ifnull("U_LeadBy",'')=''  and ifnull("ItemCode",'')<>'' and ("ItemCode"||"CardCode")=:list_of_cols_val_tab_del ;
 IF :CNT1>0 THEN
        ERROR := 122;
       ERROR_MESSAGE := 'pls updateU_LeadBy ';
     END IF;
END IF;

entry.title: Re: Growth Rebate in Condition Contract
entry.content:
On your comment, ‚Äúreward only if 2025 sales exceed 2024 by 15%‚Äù, YoY growth-based rebates are not directly supported. You‚Äôll need to simulate the growth logic using custom condition base values or enhancement. Try the below approach

Create Two Condition Contracts; one for Contract A (Base Year ‚Äì 2024) where you can capture actual sales volume and Contract B (Target Year ‚Äì 2025) to define rebate condition with a threshold.  These two condition types to be inserted to your existing pricing procedure which is related to CCM or you can copy the existing PP and create a new PP where you can add these two condition types.

Use Custom Condition Base Value Routine via VOFM to calculate

  • 2025 sales volume
  • Compare it to 2024 volume
  • Apply rebate only if growth > 15%

Use a percentage-based condition (e.g., 5% rebate). Apply it only to the incremental volume exceeding the 15% threshold. Run periodic settlement or final settlement to generate credit memos. Use delta accruals if needed to adjust monthly postings.

If you are not a SD consultant, ask your SD consultant to try the above approach.

entry.title: Blog: Managing Master Inspection Charactersitics (MICs) through ABAP
entry.content:
This post is still a work in progress...


In this blog post I will post an overview of how to manage MICs through an ABAP program
There are no dedicated BAPIs for MIC handling.

The FM 'BAPI_QPMK_SAVEREPLICA' will be used instead of various BAPIs to Create, Change and Delete MICs

Creating new MIC

Use FM 'BAPI_QPMK_SAVEREPLICA'
Input tables: 

  • MSTCHA (Master Characteristic Data)
    Key data for the MIC:
    • FUNCTION: Set to '009' for creating new MIC
    • PLANT_QPMK: Plant that MIC should be associated with
    • MSTR_CHAR: The Master Characteristic Number you want to be associated with the new MIC. 
      Find the number range setting in SPRO IMG ‚Üí Quality Management ‚Üí Quality Planning ‚Üí Basic Data ‚Üí Inspection Characteristic ‚Üí Define Number Ranges. If a number range is maintained as internal then you can leave this field blank and that number range will be used. Otherwise use FM 'NUMBER_GET_NEXT' for object 'QMERKNR' and provide the interval key maintained in SNRO. 
    • VMSTR_CHAR: Version nr, set as '000001' for new MIC
    • VALID_FROM: Set as desired
    • QLOESCHKZ: Release status of MIC. Set as '2' for "released". Set as '1' for "Being created" if you do not want to release MIC immediately.
    • QVOLLST: Copy Model/Reference Characteristic. Initial for "Incomplete Copy Model", '1' for "Complete copy model" and 'X' for "Reference characteristic".
    • IND_CONTROL: This field represents the Characteristic Control Indicator selections. I have not found definitive documentation for how to de-/encode this field. I recommend having a template MIC and copying the corresponding QPMK-STEUERKZ field. 
  • MSTCHA_TEXT
    Text data for the MIC:
    • PLANT_QPMK; Provide the same plant as in the Key structure
    • MSTR_CHAR: Provide the same Master Characteristic Number as in the Key structure. If using an internal number range, you must pre-allocate it by calling the 'NUMBER_GET_NEXT' FM (OBJECT = 'QMERKMALE', SUBOBJECT = <plant>, NR_RANGE_NR = '<your internal interval>'). Remember to apply CONVERSION_EXIT_ALPHA_INPUT.
    • VMSTR_CHAR: Provide the same version as in the Key structure
    • VALID_FROM: Provide the same valid from as in the Key structure
    • LANGU/LANGU_ISO: Provide the language that they text should be active for or leave blank for system language.
    • CHAR_DESCR: Provide short text
    • IND_MST_CHA_LTEXT: Flag whether long text exists

entry.title: Re: Unable to Update Bank Directories in Bulk
entry.content:
1. Use the Import Bank Directories app to upload bank directories in bulk.
  2. Upload the relevant files and compare them with the existing bank data.
  3. Save the new and modified data into the bank master table using a global bank directory.

entry.title: Re: Email notifications for the buyer when a Goods Receip...
entry.content:
Ensure Buyer Has a Valid Email in SAP User Master su01. Under Address, make sure the email address is maintained in the Communication section. If the buyer is not a SAP user, you‚Äôll need to use a generic email address or create a dummy user with the correct email. In MN21, you can consider a Partner Function like PE or Created By. SAP then uses the partner data from the PO or GR document to identify the relevant user. If that user has a valid email address maintained in SU01, and the output method is set to External Send, the system routes the email accordingly.

Finally and most importantly, ensure Requirement 171 is assigned to MLGR in the procedure. This requirement ensures the output triggers only when a GR or SES is posted.

entry.title: Re: Alternative for Advanced Financial Closing
entry.content: Advanced financial closing can be time-consuming and complex, especially for companies managing large volumes of data. A practical alternative is adopting cloud-based automation tools that streamline reconciliation, reporting, and compliance. These tools reduce errors and improve accuracy in the closing cycle. Businesses also benefit from real-time dashboards and cross-department collaboration. Interestingly, even industries like iGaming use such technology to ensure transparency in transactions‚Äîsee how platforms like https://icasinoreviews.co.nz/2-dollar-deposit-casino/ manage low-deposit systems effectively. Embracing smarter financial solutions enhances agility and strategic decision-making across all sectors.

entry.title: Edit not possible: locking of entity failed
entry.content:

I have two entities: parent and child. 

When in Edit mode,  spamming the 'Create' button of the child entity results in the error 'Edit not possible: locking of entity 'Parent' failed'.

The problem is that after this the child section keeps 'loading' and the whole page kind of breaks because nothing happens after I click on discard draft or when trying to go back.

What can I do in this situation? Is there a way I can catch the error or a way of stopping the user from spamming the create button?

entry.title: Missing point of configuration to assign the edocument type for FI-CA document type SAPPublic cloud
entry.content:
I have compared one on premise FI-CA configuration with public cloud.

In on premise there is one configuration point to assign the FI-CA document type to the edocument type that seems to be missing in Public cloud. The link in on premise SPRO is this one:

IMG/Funciones de aplicaci√≥n generales/eDocument/Parametrizaciones generales/Assign eDocument Type to Accounting Document Type for FI-CA (TVFKEDOCV)

With the edocument type you can assign different types whenever the Invoice is an incoming invoice, outgoing invoice, adjustment invoice:

This configuration point, is not presented in SAP public cloud for FI-CA neither CI documents. It is just presented for FI and SD billing documents:

 

I‚Äôm not sure if we can activate any scope item in order to add this point of configuration for FI-CA documents. The scope items 5XU and 78L have been already activated.

In other hand, In the SAP documentation, I have found this:

Configuration Options for Key Users in Contract Accounting | SAP Help Portal

I can not see in this documentation where I can assign the edocument type for FI-CA.

Right now as I can not assign the edocument type, edocument is failing with the incoming invoices:

The system seems to be selecting for all the documents the SII Outgoing Invoice.

Could someone help me to see where can I assign the edocument type to the FI-CA document in SAP Public cloud?

Thanks

 

#FI-CA #BRIM  #CI #SAP PUBLIC CLOUD

entry.title: Re: Data Migration Cockpit - QM Inspection Plan PLKN (Gro...
entry.content:
Dear Yuri6542,

thank you for the details provided. 

The field PLNKN is an internal counter, there is no option to add/change it via transaction QP01/QP02 or via BAPI BAPI_INSPECTIONPLAN_CREATE either. As the migration object for inspection plan is based on the BAPI, it is not an option to update the PLNKN with the migration cockpit either. It should be assigned internally, automatically.

I wish you a nice day,
‚ÄãAlbert
‚Äã***
‚ÄãRead and follow the 'SAP Community Rules of Engagement' at
‚Äãhttps://www.sap.com/community/about/rules-of-engagement.html

entry.title: Re: Auto suggestion in Simple Property
entry.content: Simple property doesn't have any look ahead suggestion capabilities.  The best suggestion might be to use a list picker with search.  Since it sounds like the value has to be a match you can display the list of users and as they start typing in the search the list will automatically filter down.

entry.title: Re: To avoid the DIV/ERROR in a calculated measure
entry.content:
Put an IF stmt around it to check that the denominator is not zero or null.

IF (ISNULL([FC1 2025]) OR [FC1 2025] = 0, null, [Strategy 2026]/[FC1 2025] - 1)

entry.title: Add @sap/cds v8 service to existing project that uses v7 using existing db
entry.content:
Hi,

I would like to add a new UI5 application using odata v4 and an Analytical Table to our current mta application using @SAP/cds v7. 
The Analytical Table sends queries that could only be processed with  @SAP/cds v8 service, v7 gives errors like Feature is not supported: Transformation "CONCAT" with query option $apply
I would like to use the db of the existing mta application for that new service.

 Do you have any suggestion?

I have some ideas but struggling with both:

  • adding the new service to the current mta app
    • upgrading @SAP/cds - there's a lot of custom code to rewrite, not ideal
    • adding the new v8 service without upgrading @SAP/cds in the whole project, having a package.json in the new service folder with @SAP/cds v8 - not tried that yet, just came into my mind
  • creating a new app using the existing db
    • define the current db as existing service - I cannot make the xsuaa to work so far
    •  consume the existing hdi container - all the examples I found using schema name and role, but I see no option defining those for the hdi container
      e.g. https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/how-to-consume-existing-database-container-in-sap-cloud-application/ba-p/13559865
      https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/hana-cloud-access-cross-container-schema.html

 Any help would be appreciated.

Best,
Peter

entry.title: Re: GRIR has a positive open balance Error
entry.content:
Some of the possible causes are

  • even if quantities match, exchange rate differences, delivery costs, or taxes can cause mismatches. Use transaction MB03 or ME23N to inspect PO history and compare GR and IR amounts line by line.
  • Check if the GR and IR were posted to different GR/IR accounts due to incorrect account determination in OBYC. This can cause the amounts to offset in different places, leaving one account with a residual balance.
  • If IR was posted manually without referencing the GR, the system may not clear the GR/IR account properly. Use FBL3N to analyze line items in the GR/IR account and look for unmatched entries.
  • A partial reversal of GR or IR can leave behind a balance. Check for reversal documents in MBST or MR8M and confirm they match the original postings.

entry.title: Re: CKMLPRKEKO lot size change ?
entry.content:
In your case, why CKMLPRKEKO Lot Sizes vary is because, the LOSGR field in CKMLPRKEKO reflects the lot size used during cost estimate creation, not the standard lot size from the material master. If cost estimates were created manually or via different costing variants, the lot size could have been set arbitrarily or defaulted from templates.

What you can do is go to transaction OKKN and check your costing variant. Under Quantity Structure and Valuation, ensure the lot size determination is consistent across materials. When running cost estimates, explicitly set the desired lot size. If using CK40N for mass costing, you can predefine lot sizes via selection parameters or user exits.

Of course, compare KALNR (Cost Estimate Number) with the corresponding costing runs. This helps trace back which run introduced which lot size.

entry.title: Re: VAKEY field not available in NACH table in S4/HANA
entry.content:
In S/4HANA, direct access to VAKEY is deprecated. You can't rely on it for custom logic or reporting as you did in ECC. SAP recommends reconstructing VAKEY using condition record number and A-table content, rather than accessing it directly.

One workaround is SAP provides CL_COND_VAKEY_SRV to reconstruct VAKEY dynamically. You can use methods from this class in custom ABAP logic to retrieve output determination parameters. Alternatively, you can use RV_CONDITION_RECORD_READ which helps retrieve condition records and can be used to rebuild VAKEY logic indirectly.

Also, have a look at SAP Note 2220005 which outlines data model changes in pricing and condition technique and includes examples for handling VAKEY replacements

entry.title: Re: SAP MDG Mass Processing ‚Äì Extend feature ‚Äú_ACTION_CODE‚Äù
entry.content:
What is the best way to handle extending to a plant that has multiple plants and one of the other plants is giving an error about it's data.  Can the plant be excluded during mass updates.

Example:

Material 1 is exteded to plant 100, 200, 300

Material 2 is extended to plant 200, 300

Now I'm extending both materials to 400.  During activation Material 1 is giving an error on plant 100.  The user is not responsible for that plant so they don't want to update it.  How can they get around this error?

entry.title: Guidance for Adjusting Drill Limits in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) for end users
entry.content:
Hi Community,

In SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), when a table exceeds the default drill limit of 500 rows or 60 columns, a warning symbol (‚ö†Ô∏è) appears. While I understand that users can manually adjust the drill limit by hovering over the warning and selecting ‚ÄúEdit Drill Limitation‚Äù, I‚Äôm looking for the best way to guide end users through this process effectively.

Specifically, I‚Äôd like to know:

  • Is there a recommended way to display a message or popup within the story or analytic application to instruct users on how to change the drill limit? need steps how to do this?
  • Can this be automated or triggered when the warning appears?
  • Are there any best practices or UI/UX suggestions for making this guidance more intuitive for business users?

Any insights, examples, or documentation links would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks in advance,
Govardhana Rao Vegi

entry.title: Re: Missing Post Processing for Odata Inteface - S/4HANA...
entry.content:
Hello @Phil_P,

Thanks for raising this interesting question. It‚Äôs indeed a common challenge people face in S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition.

Below listed are the core issues:

  • OData APIs give you real-time responses and error messages
    But they‚Äôre not supported by AIF, so no monitoring or reprocessing
  • SOAP (async) APIs are AIF-compatible
    But they don‚Äôt return immediate responses

This limitation is confirmed in SAP Note 3405212 and SAP KBAs 3461312 and 3567043.

Unfortunately, hybrid solutions (OData & SOAP) aren‚Äôt supported in the Public Cloud due to extensibility constraints. If both features are critical, I would recommend raising it via the SAP Influence Portal.

For further information, kindly refer to the below SAP link:

Available Monitoring Content

I am happy to discuss options further if needed.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: How to create a measure in SAC that always shows a fixed month value regardless of the data filter
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am working in SAP Analytics Cloud with an import model based on an Excel file.

I need to create a calculated measure that should always display the value of another measure restricted to a specific month (e.g., January), but it should remain visible across all months in the story, even if a date filter is applied.

Example:

  • I have a measure [Legacy Book Value Assets].

  • I want to create another measure that takes only the value of [Legacy Book Value Assets] for January 2025.

  • When I filter the story for June 2025, I still want this "January-based" measure to be displayed for every month (replicated), instead of disappearing because of the date filter.

I tried using a Restricted Measure for January, but when I change the date filter in the story, the measure goes blank.

Is there a way to define this logic directly in the model (calculated measure), so that the value for January remains visible across all months, regardless of the story filters?

Any workaround, formula example, model design best practice would be highly appreciated but please do not consider Data Action solutions.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Re: AATP Supply Protection with "physical stock" protection
entry.content:
Hello,
with Supply Protection it is possible to do this. However, protection has to be seen as "restriction for others". With the default setting of SUP the demand matching the highest priority could get the complete stock (if it comes first) as this demand doesn't need to consider the other protections as restriction.
There are also other settings and various options regarding the restriction logic, how time buckets with protected quantities have to be considered or how the own protected quantities are considered.
There is one quite comprehensive blog I like to recommend: Supply Protection In a Nutshell - SAP Community

entry.title: Key User Custom Fields: Maximum number of fields and characters
entry.content:
Key User Custom Fields: Maximum number of fields and characters

Have you ever wondered how many key user custom fields you could add to a specific business context? If so, this blog post is for you.

This blog post covers the following topics:

  • The maximum number of key user custom fields you can add
  • The maximum overall number of characters consumed by key user custom fields

Please note that for all S/4HANA editions, the actual numbers for the maximum fields and maximum overall number characters supported strongly depend on the S/4HANA release. In general, the maximum number of fields and the maximum overall number of characters consumed by key user custom fields have been significantly increased over time.

S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, you can figure out easily how much capacity for a given business context is left. This is directly shown while creating a new field using the Custom Fields app (see screenshot below).

Business Context Capacity

The field ‚ÄúBusiness Context Capacity‚Äù displays a percentage number telling you which percentage of the overall available capacity reserved for customers has already been consumed. When you hover over the ‚ÄúBusiness Context Capacity‚Äù bar, you see how many fields and how many bytes are available (see screenshot). As a rule of thumb, you can divide the number of bytes by factor 2 to get the free number of characters.

Please note that for each business context, the responsible SAP application department defines the capacity available for customers individually. The only guard rail that exists is that the number of fields reserved for customers is never less than 100 fields and never less than 1000 characters.
If the available business context capacity is not sufficient for you, please create a request via the customer influence channel or create a customer ticket on the application component of the respective business context.

S/4HANA and S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition

In S/4HANA and S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, the business context capacity limits are not considered at all. You can add key user custom fields until you reach the technical limits given by ABAP dictionary. As soon as you reach these limits, you'll no longer be able to add additional key user custom fields. A popup will tell you that there is no more space left to create key user custom fields.

These limits are very high. For SAP_BASIS releases above 7.95, no customer has reached these limits yet.

The ABAP dictionary limits relevant in this context are:

  1. The maximum number of fields: the maximum number of fields supported in a database table. Note that for counting them, it's not relevant whether this field is a SAP standard field or not
  2. The maximum table width: this figure tells you how many bytes at max per table entry in a database table are supported. Note that for counting them, it's not relevant whether the bytes originate from a SAP standard field or not

Let‚Äôs have a look at these limits:

  1. Maximum Number of Fields
    • A database table can have up to 749 fields by default
    • Since SAP-BASIS release 7.73, the limit increases to:
      • 1,500 fields for application tables with a 'Column' storage type.
      • 1,000 fields for application tables with a 'Row' storage type
    • Since SAP-BASIS release 9.16, the limit has been further increased to:
      • 3000 fields for application tables with a 'Column' storage type
      • 1,000 fields for application tables with a 'Row' storage type (remained unchanged)
  2. Maximum Table Width
    • By default, the maximum width of a table is 4,030 characters
    • With the TABLEN feature activated (DDIC table DD02L, field TABLEN_FEATURE), the limit increases to 16,293 characters
    • Since SAP-BASIS release 7.95, the table width limit has been extended further to 256,000 characters

With this, we are done. I hope this blog helps you understand what the limits of key user custom fields are regarding number of fields and number of bytes.

Feedback, Comments, or Questions:

You‚Äôre cordially invited to provide them in the comments section below. Please follow my profile to get updates when I publish more posts on these topics.
Feel invited to post and answer questions here (https://answers.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26) and read other posts on the topic (https://blogs.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26/).

I want to thank Yasmina van Rooij (YasminavanRooij), Karsten Schaser (Karsten_Schaser) for their extremely helpful contributions.

Other related blog posts (just a small selection of the blogs available for custom field extensibility)

  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/convert-manually-created-append-fields-to-real-key-user-custom-fields/ba-p/13967399
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/key-user-custom-fields-in-s-4hana-cloud-private-edition-and-on-premise-dos/ba-p/14026871

entry.title: What's New in SAP Asset Performance Management 2507
entry.content:
The 2507 release brings a set of thoughtful enhancements designed to improve your user experience and efficiency.

At the center of this release is our new View Rule Logs app, giving you immediate insight into rule execution and helping you take the right actions faster.

Let's take a closer look.

Introducing Our New App - 'View Rule Logs'

Understanding how your business rules perform is key to ensuring reliable automation. Our new app View Rule Logs, gives you real-time visibility into the execution of business rules‚Äîwhether they ran successfully or encountered issues. With this insight, you can:

  • Verify execution outcomes, such as whether alerts were triggered, notifications were sent, or external events were created as expected.

  • View and take recommended follow-up actions

  • Quickly diagnose logic or data issues by pinpointing where rules failed due to missing inputs or configuration errors, so you don't have to work it out yourself.

Watch this short video to see it in action.

Video: View Rule Logs application

For more information, see the SAP Help Portal View Rule Logs.

 

Enhanced Filtering by Characteristic Value

The Characteristic Value value help popup in the Select Technical Object window has been enhanced in 2507 to improve usability and search efficiency.

Previously, users had to filter assets by first selecting a class and characteristic - even if they already knew the characteristic value. This was time-consuming and led to usability complaints.

With the new enhancements, users benefit from:

  • A Characteristic Value filter to refine results directly based on known values.
  • A free text search bar that quickly filters across class, characteristic and characteristic value fields.

Now, if a user knows the characteristic value (e.g. Voltage = 220V), they can enter it directly to filter assets. That means there's no need to navigate through class and characteristic first. The older method remains available for users who prefer it.

These improvements enable faster and more precise selection of technical objects, especially useful during assessments, recommendations, or rule processing.

Filter by characteristic value

Spot Critical Alerts Faster with Deduplication Count in List View

High-frequency alerts can indicate critical issues, but until now, spotting them at a glance wasn‚Äôt easy. Our latest enhancement to the Manage Alerts screen solves this by introducing a visible Deduplication Count directly in the list view.

This new column helps you immediately recognize which alert types are repeatedly triggering, without needing to open each alert detail page. 

The Deduplication Count is now available under column settings and is enabled by default. When deduplication is active, the count begins at zero and increases as duplicate alerts are grouped. This helps you prioritize action based on real-time alert frequency.

For added usability, a new Last Updated On column has also been positioned between Occurred On and Deduplication Count, making it easier to filter and track the most recent changes.

This small but powerful improvement brings greater clarity and responsiveness to alert management.

Stay Informed and Get Involved

    • For an exhaustive list of all new features, visit the SAP Help Portal - What's New in SAP Asset Performance Management.. 
    • Submit or vote for the improvement you would like to see in the SAP Continuous Influence session.

See you soon for the 2508 update!

entry.title: Re: Access to Historical Production Orders incl. BOMs aft...
entry.content:
Hello Christian, thank you for your question!

Hope this help you a little bit!

  1. SAP Document Management Service (DMS)

    • SAP DMS can be used to manage and archive documents in a cloud environment. It provides document storage, versioning, and access control features that can be integrated with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

  2. SAP S/4HANA Cloud Archiving

    • SAP offers cloud-based archiving solutions that can be used to archive historical data. These solutions can be integrated with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to provide access to archived data.

  3. SAP Data Archiving Service (DAS) on SAP BTP

    • SAP DAS on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) provides data archiving capabilities for cloud environments. It allows you to archive historical data while maintaining access to it through predefined access patterns.

Data Migration

In addition to the migration approach ‚ÄúMigrate Data Using Staging Tables‚Äù, the SAP S/4HANA Cloud migration cockpit now facilitates the direct transfer of business data from an SAP ECC source system to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Using a communication arrangement to connect to the source system, it selects data automatically, i.e., it uses the selection criteria company code and the migration objects to identify and transfer relevant data. A migration object describes how to migrate data for a specific business object to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. To adjust the selection of data, the SAP S/4HANA Cloud migration object modeler can be used.  Get started now and visit the SAP Help portal for all related information! Visit here to see a comprehensive list of migration objects available for direct transfer.  <https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/highlights-of-the-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition-2402-release/ba-p/13587480>

entry.title: Unlocking the Power of Events: A Deep Dive into the Event Add-on for ERP
entry.content:
Unlocking the Power of Events: A Deep Dive into the Event Add-on for ERP

In Part 1 of this blog series, we introduced SAP‚Äôs Event Add-on for ERP ‚Äì a game-changer for integrating SAP ECC and S/4HANA more easily into event-driven architectures. In this follow-up article, we take a feature-focused look at the Add-on ‚Äì exploring how it works, what technical capabilities it offers, why it plays a central role in decoupling, scalability, and agility when event-enabling SAP backends.

Whether you're running SAP ECC 6.0, SAP S/4HANA (on-premise or private cloud), or are currently in the process of transitioning between versions, the Event Add-on for ERP provides a no-code/low-code, flexible, and scalable way to enable real-time, event-driven communication across your SAP ecosystem.

A Feature-Rich Solution Built for Modern Integration

At its core, the Event Add-on for ERP enables SAP systems to send and receive business events in real-time.

It provides a robust framework for configuration, payload design, event triggering, and connectivity. Together, these components form a runtime and configuration layer that transforms traditional SAP applications into real-time event producers and consumers:

Building Blocks of the Event Add-On for ERP

At a high level, the Add-on operates by detecting meaningful changes in SAP business processes - such as the creation of a sales order, an update to a vendor record, or a goods movement posting - and translating them into well-structured event messages. These messages are then published to external systems through asynchronous, decoupled communication channels and SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh as event broker.

The process begins in the SAP application layer, where various types of event triggers are captured. These triggers can originate from standard SAP mechanisms like Business Object Repository (BOR) events, Change Documents (CDHDR/CDPOS), IDoc creation, or Output Determination routines. In more modern S/4HANA systems, the Add-on can also listen to RAP (RESTful ABAP Programming) event triggers.

Once a trigger is detected, the Add-on initiates a payload generation process. Instead of requiring custom ABAP code, this process is driven by a visual tool called the Payload Designer. With this tool, users define the event content by selecting SAP tables, fields, joins, and optional filters. Hierarchical structures are also supported, as are CDS views and standard IDoc formats. The resulting payload is stored as a transportable configuration object, not code.

Payload Designer for codeless configuration of events

In the following paragraphs, the most impactful features are described in greater detail.

 

Codeless Event Design and Payload Configuration

One of the standout aspects of the Event Add-on for ERP is its Payload Designer, which enables users to define and configure outbound interfaces without writing a single line of code.

  • Visually select SAP tables, fields, and joins.
  • Design flat or hierarchical payloads using tables or CDS views.
  • Store configurations in transportable objects.
  • Extend or customize payloads with Z-fields or Z-tables as needed.

This approach reduces implementation time dramatically, especially for teams with limited ABAP skills.

One of the most compelling aspects of the Event Add-on is how flexibly it allows event definitions to be created, extended, or customized‚Äîall without modifying SAP standard code. In a typical scenario, a user begins by selecting from a rich library of predefined events. These cover common SAP objects such as sales orders, purchase orders, deliveries, goods movements, accounting documents, and many more.

If business needs go beyond the standard, users can extend these definitions. For example, you might add custom Z-fields to an existing payload or link additional SAP CDS views to include extra data. You can even build entirely custom events from scratch, using the Payload Designer, selecting any combination of fields, structures, and joins from the underlying SAP data model.

The outbound message design supports dynamic topics on the broker, so that consumers can subscribe to event topics based on content (e.g., only sales orders from a certain region) without hardcoding endpoints, which is a unique feature of SAP Advanced Event Mesh.

 

Supported Event Triggers ‚Äì Flexibility Without Custom Coding

The Event Add-on supports a wide range of trigger types, enabling it to detect changes in both standard and custom business processes. These include:

Standard Triggers

  • SAP Business Object Repository (BOR) Events
  • SAP RAP Events (available for S/4HANA 2023+)
  • Change Documents (CDHDR/CDPOS)
  • SAP IDoc
  • Business Transaction Events (BTE)
  • SAP Output Determination

Custom Trigger Options

  • Manual ABAP triggers (function call to API)
  • Scheduled jobs (batch exports)
  • Custom object event registration via configuration

These triggers cover a wide spectrum: from high-volume transactional updates (e.g. goods movements) to master data changes (e.g. material or customer master).

The versatility in trigger definition allows for both real-time and batch-style processing.

 

Real-Time & Batch Processing Modes

You can configure the Add-on to push a message immediately when a record is created or changed, or to run scheduled jobs that extract and publish data in batches or micro-batches. The Add-on even supports initial full loads, making it suitable for bootstrapping event consumers or for high-volume use .

Depending on business needs, the Event Add-on supports:

  • Real-time push of single events
  • Scheduled batch transmissions or micro-batching for high-volume near-real-time events
  • Initial mass loads for historical data
  • Packed delta processing for optimal performance

This makes it ideal for hybrid scenarios: from low-latency retail use cases to massive data distribution across global instances.

 

Bi-Directional Integration: Outbound and Inbound

After the payload is created, the message is dispatched to the configured endpoint. The Add-on handles delivery asynchronously, with support for failover strategies, retries, and high-availability scenarios.

Events can not only be sent from SAP to external systems, making SAP and event - but also received into SAP from external event producers, making the Event Add-on a bi-directional component.

Inbound flows use JSON structures, which are mapped either to a standard IDoc or a generic IDoc structure and then handed off to BAPIs or custom logic for posting into the SAP system. In case the incoming structure corresponds to a standard IDoc in the SAP system, the event message can be mapped automatically to the IDoc. For custom structures, a mapping logic is required.

All outbound and inbound activity is traceable in the Add-on‚Äôs monitoring UI, and message content is stored for auditing or reprocessing.

 

Architecture & Connectivity

The Add-on is designed to work seamlessly with the SAP Business Technology Platform and especially SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh (AEM). It runs in the ABAP application layer and operates through modular components that handle both trigger detection and message creation.

Key Architecture Components (as found in the diagram above):

  • Event Trigger Layer: Connects to event sources and listens to changes: BOR events, IDocs, Change Docs, BTEs, RAP BOs
  • Outbound & Inbound Connectors: Communication with Advanced Event Mesh
  • Payload Designer: UI-based tool for codeless interface configuration and payload structures from tables or CDS views
  • Monitoring & Administration Console: For error handling, alerts, reprocessing

High-availability features like dynamic topic routing, failover, and endpoint confirmation ensure reliability and resiliency across cloud or hybrid environments.

 

Performance, Reliability, and Scalability

Scalability and performance have been built into the Add-on from the ground up. This is achieved through multi-threaded processing, efficient payload generation, and configurable performance thresholds making sure that end-users are not affected by large, parallelized background jobs.

Resilience is also a core feature. The monitoring UI allows administrators to track message status, identify errors, trigger automatic and manual reprocessing, and configure alerts for delivery failures or downstream issues. The system is designed for high availability, with failover support, retry queues, and robust error isolation.

These capabilities make the Add-on suitable not just for niche integration cases, but for enterprise-scale workloads where SAP serves as a real-time data source.

 

Governance

Event definitions created in the SAP Event Add-on for ERP can be exported as Async API specifications and imported into the Event Portal module of AEM. This way, event definitions can be catalogued and published for discovery by potential consumers. This facilitates re-use of events and promotes standardization of events and interfaces.

In addition, the add-on comes with a clean core check feature to validate the data sources used in the payload design. It recommends suitable CDS views as replacement of deprecated table views to support clean core readiness.

 

Summary: Why You Should Care

The Event Add-on for ERP offers a comprehensive, extensible, and modern way to bring SAP systems into the real-time, decoupled, cloud-first architecture demanded by today‚Äôs IT strategy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Unified framework for S/4HANA and SAP ECC: Works with both ECC and S/4HANA, supports migration and hybrid setups
  • No-code/low-code interface design
  • Accelerated Time-to-Event:  Go live quickly with predefined templates and no-code tooling
  • Real-time outbound & inbound integration
  • Full support for standard & custom events
  • Reduces maintenance cost compared to custom ABAP interfaces or legacy middleware
  • Clean-core compliant: Avoid deep customizations thanks to configuration-based design
  • Performance: Proven in enterprise environments with millions of events per day
  • Built-in monitoring, resilience & scalability

If you‚Äôre looking to break the chains of point-to-point integrations, simplify middleware, or begin your journey toward event-driven enterprise architecture ‚Äì the Event Add-on for ERP is your gateway.

In the next part of this blog series, we will walk through a real configuration example: from event definition to payload creation, to endpoint delivery using SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh. Stay tuned.

 

Links

Here are some links that provide you with additional information on the Event Add-On for ERP:

SAP Help: Connecting the Add-On to AEM

SAP Discovery Center for AEM and Event Add-On

Discovery Center Mission on Event Add-On for ERP and Advanced Event Mesh

entry.title: TMG Event 01: Error message in FORM on_save_change not showing immediately on screen
entry.content:
image_1image_2Hi expert, this is my sap abap code which i use to maintain event on table maintainance generator. In this code I have create a form on_save_change to handle event 01: Before saving the data in the database. In on_save_change form, i have create 2 code to validate email duplicate and empty key field value. But whenever i tried to test these two test case, the system always exit and then it show the message outside. Please give me detailed solution

FORM on_save_changes.

  FIELD-SYMBOLS: <fs_field> TYPE any.

  " Existing loop to update audit fields for changed records
  LOOP AT total.
    CHECK <action> EQ aendern.
    ASSIGN COMPONENT 'AENAM' OF STRUCTURE <vim_total_struc> TO <fs_field>.
    IF sy-subrc = 0.
      <fs_field> = sy-uname.
    ENDIF.
    ASSIGN COMPONENT 'AEDAT' OF STRUCTURE <vim_total_struc> TO <fs_field>.
    IF sy-subrc = 0.
      <fs_field> = sy-datum.
    ENDIF.
    ASSIGN COMPONENT 'AEZET' OF STRUCTURE <vim_total_struc> TO <fs_field>.
    IF sy-subrc = 0.
      <fs_field> = sy-uzeit.
    ENDIF.
    READ TABLE extract WITH KEY <vim_xtotal_key>.
    IF sy-subrc = 0.
      extract = total.
      MODIFY extract INDEX sy-tabix.
    ENDIF.
    MODIFY total.
  ENDLOOP.

  " Check for duplicate EMAIL_ADDRESS
  DATA: lt_email TYPE HASHED TABLE OF string WITH UNIQUE KEY table_line,
        lv_email_lower TYPE string.
  FIELD-SYMBOLS: <fs_email> TYPE zsap03_email-email_address.

  LOOP AT total.
    ASSIGN COMPONENT 'EMAIL_ADDRESS' OF STRUCTURE <vim_total_struc> TO <fs_email>.
    IF sy-subrc = 0 AND <fs_email> IS NOT INITIAL.
      lv_email_lower = to_lower( <fs_email> ).
      READ TABLE lt_email WITH KEY table_line = lv_email_lower TRANSPORTING NO FIELDS.
      IF sy-subrc = 0.
        MESSAGE e022(zsap03_msg_cl) WITH <fs_email>.
      ELSE.
        INSERT lv_email_lower INTO TABLE lt_email.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.
  ENDLOOP.

" Check for empty key fields (assuming group 'KEY' corresponds to key fields)
  DATA: lt_fieldinfo TYPE TABLE OF dfies,
        ls_fieldinfo TYPE dfies.

  CALL FUNCTION 'DDIF_FIELDINFO_GET'
    EXPORTING
      tabname        = 'ZSAP03_EMAIL'
    TABLES
      dfies_tab      = lt_fieldinfo
    EXCEPTIONS
      not_found      = 1
      internal_error = 2
      OTHERS         = 3.

  IF sy-subrc = 0.
    LOOP AT lt_fieldinfo INTO ls_fieldinfo WHERE keyflag = 'X'.
      LOOP AT total.
        ASSIGN COMPONENT ls_fieldinfo-fieldname OF STRUCTURE <vim_total_struc> TO <fs_field>.
        IF sy-subrc = 0 AND <fs_field> IS INITIAL.
          MESSAGE e111(zsap03_msg_cl) WITH ls_fieldinfo-fieldname.
        ENDIF.
      ENDLOOP.
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDIF.

ENDFORM.
